moves.3... Nc6: Controlling the e5 square and preparing Nf6.
moves.4. c3: ?! White risks to fall back in development. There is no way he can play d2-d4 on the next move, therefore his 4. c3 is pointless.
moves.4... Nf6: Now the d5 square is controlled and black is ready to play d7-d5.
moves.5. d3: ?! Very passive pawn play, black is already clearly better developed.
moves.7. Bb5 Bg4 8. Bxc6+: ?! The bishop made three moves to get exchanged for a knight that made just one move.
moves.8... bxc6 9. Qg3: Not a good square for the Queen - here it is vulnerable.
moves.9... Bd6: Eqploiting the position of the white Queen.
moves.10. Qe3+: If 10. Bf4 then black plays the intermezzo 10. ...Qe7
moves.10... Kd7: ! gaining another tempo - now Re8 winning the queen is threatened.
moves.11. Qd2 Re8+ 12. Kf1 Qe7: Black has developed 5 pieces while white has only one piece playing.
moves.13. f3: What else? White pieces are tied down. He tries to secure the e2 square.
moves.13... Rab8: !? The advantage in development has to be exploited as soon as possible.
moves.14. fxg4: After some thought white accepts the sacrifice.
moves.15. Nf3:
This leaves the e2 square vulnerable and black immediately regains his sacrificed piece.
How else could white continue development?
15. Na3 might look like a good alternative, but it runs into 15. ...Rxb2!! - conquering the important e3 square for the knight.
The best was 15. Qe2, but then black could continue his attack with 15. ...Qh4
moves.16... Bxc1: White can't recapture and is now completely lost. Black threatens both Ne3  and Rxb2 winning.
moves.17. Na3 Rxb2 18. Qd1 Ne3+: White either gets mated or loses his queen. He chooses to end the game quickly.
